headline: SATIRE: Gorilla association objects to GOP Gov. Larry Hogan calling Trump an 800 pounder in the room
sentences:
For example, from Wikipedia:
 Drawing of a gorilla who has killed a hunter and destroyed his shotgun, as narrated by Paul Du Chaillu, 1861
Since gaining international attention, gorillas have been a recurring element of many aspects of popular culture and media.

The term can describe a powerful geopolitical and military force, or, in business, a powerful corporate entity that has such a large majority percentage of whatever market they compete within that they can use that strength to crush would-be competitors.

[104] Several films would use the "escaped gorilla" trope including The Strange Case of Doctor Rx (1942), The Gorilla Man (1943), Gorilla at Large (1954) and the Disney cartoons The Gorilla Mystery (1930) and Donald Duck and the Gorilla (1944).

[3]
Oddly the photo Wikipedia used (right) to illustrate this entry has a caption which doesnt fit the image at all since the gorilla contentedly munching on some leaves hardly strikes fear into anybody unless they suffer from Pithecophobia.

This is how Wikipedia defines the phrase:
800-pound gorilla" is an American English expression for a person or organization so powerful that it can act without regard to the rights of others or the law.
[108] More positive and sympathetic portrayals of gorillas include the films Son of Kong (1933), Mighty Joe Young (1949), Gorillas in the Mist (1988) and Instinct (1999) and the 1992 novel Ishmael.
When it come down to it, if it was literally true that 800 pound gorillas were present in as many rooms as people said they were they were present in more historic situations than Forrest Gump.
Hogan wanted a more accurate simile to describe Trumps influence he should have used Godzilla, the enormous, destructive, prehistoric sea monster awakened and empowered by nuclear radiation.

The International Association of Gorillas has long objected to the disparaging use of the term 800-pound gorilla? which is usually expanded to 800-pound gorilla in the room?.
Like the other great apes, gorillas can laugh, grieve, have "rich emotional lives", develop strong family bonds, make and use tools, and think about the past and future.

Axios, in their article Exclusive: Hogan predicts Trump will lose GOP stranglehold post-midterms? reported that Hogan said:
"President Trump is the 800-pound gorilla.
The real 800 pound gorilla in the political room, really gorillas (plural), are the growing numbers of his previous supporters who see him for the Godzilla he is.
[12]They have been shown to have cultures in different areas revolving around different methods of food preparation, and will show individual colour preferences.
But in the scientific community, it's a settled question: 95 percent of scientists believe this is happening with 100 percent confidence temperatures are rising.

It is often used in a simple descriptive way, for example:
Climate change is the 800-pound gorilla in the living room that the media dances around.
In law, the phrase occurs semi-(in)formally as a characterization of judges vs. courts; as in: "Standard/Court Rule" vs "Gorilla/Judge Rule".

[12]
The gorilla association has long attempted to counter their depiction in popular culture as dangerous villains (image on right).

Gorillas have been used as opponents to jungle-themed heroes such as Tarzan and Sheena, Queen of the Jungle.
Unlike Trumps star, nobody ever saw fit to take a sledge hammer to it like they did with Trumps star (article).
Inspired by Emmanuel Frmiet's Gorilla Carrying off a Woman, gorillas have been depicted kidnapping human women.
He's still popular among many segments of the base ... but it's diminished dramatically since the election."
